hints_html:
The mean is defined by

\(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx\)

The substitution from part i will be useful.
hints_latex:
The substitution from
{part
i} will be useful.
hints_raw:
The mean is defined by

<math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx</math>
The substitution from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2013/Question_03_(b)_i|part i]] will be useful.
question: 3 (b) ii
sols_html:
We seek to compute

\(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx = \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx = \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx\)

Let \(\displaystyle u = 1-x\) so that \(\displaystyle du = -dx\), \(\displaystyle u(0) = 1\), \(\displaystyle u(q) = 1-q\) and substituting gives

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx \\ &= \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \,dx\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}}\,dx\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1-q} \frac{-(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{1-2u+u^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \sqrt{u}^{-1}-2\sqrt{u}+u^{3/2}\,du\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(2\sqrt{u}-\frac{4u^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2u^{5/2}}{5}\right) \big|_{1-q}^{1}\\ &= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(\left(2\sqrt{1}-\frac{4(1)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1)^{5/2}}{5}\right) - \left(2\sqrt{1-q}-\frac{4(1-q)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1-q)^{5/2}}{5}\right)\right) \\ &= \frac{3}{4}\left(2-\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{5}\right) \\ &= \frac{4}{5}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We seek to compute

$\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx = \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx = \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx$

Let $\displaystyle u = 1-x$ so that $\displaystyle du = -dx$,
$\displaystyle u(0) = 1$, $\displaystyle u(q) = 1-q$ and substituting
gives

\begin{align*}
\overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx \\
&= \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \,dx\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}}\,dx\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1-q} \frac{-(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{1-2u+u^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \sqrt{u}^{-1}-2\sqrt{u}+u^{3/2}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(2\sqrt{u}-\frac{4u^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2u^{5/2}}{5}\right) \big|_{1-q}^{1}\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(\left(2\sqrt{1}-\frac{4(1)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1)^{5/2}}{5}\right) - \left(2\sqrt{1-q}-\frac{4(1-q)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1-q)^{5/2}}{5}\right)\right) \\
&= \frac{3}{4}\left(2-\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{5}\right) \\
&= \frac{4}{5}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We seek to compute

<math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx = \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx = \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \ dx</math>

Let <math> \displaystyle u = 1-x</math> so that <math> \displaystyle du = -dx</math>, <math> \displaystyle u(0) = 1</math>, <math> \displaystyle u(q) = 1-q</math> and substituting gives

<math> 
\begin{align}
\overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{1}xp(x)\,dx \\
&= \frac{3}{4}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}} \,dx\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{q} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{1-x}}\,dx\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1-q} \frac{-(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{(1-u)^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \frac{1-2u+u^2}{\sqrt{u}}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}}\int_{1-q}^{1} \sqrt{u}^{-1}-2\sqrt{u}+u^{3/2}\,du\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(2\sqrt{u}-\frac{4u^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2u^{5/2}}{5}\right) \big|_{1-q}^{1}\\
&= \frac{3}{4}\lim_{q \to 1^{-}} \left(\left(2\sqrt{1}-\frac{4(1)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1)^{5/2}}{5}\right) - \left(2\sqrt{1-q}-\frac{4(1-q)^{3/2}}{3}+\frac{2(1-q)^{5/2}}{5}\right)\right) \\
&= \frac{3}{4}\left(2-\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{5}\right) \\
&= \frac{4}{5}
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Continuous Probability.

Consider \(\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x}}\). Convert \(\displaystyle f(x)\) into a probability density function (pdf) \(\displaystyle p(x)\) on an interval \(\displaystyle (a,b)\)

Find the mean of \(\displaystyle p(x)\)
statement_latex:
\textbf{Continuous Probability}.

\textbf{Consider $\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x}}$. Convert
$\displaystyle f(x)$ into a probability density function (pdf)
$\displaystyle p(x)$ on an interval $\displaystyle (a,b)$}

Find the mean of $\displaystyle p(x)$

'''Continuous Probability'''. 

'''Consider <math> \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x}}</math>. Convert <math> \displaystyle f(x)</math> into a probability density function (pdf) <math> \displaystyle p(x)</math> on an interval <math> \displaystyle (a,b)</math>'''

Find the mean of <math> \displaystyle p(x)</math>
